across.text: Not as many contracts for navigator in the past
across.explanation: Abel JanszoonTASMAN(i.e. “navigator in the past”). “Contracts” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: NO(T AS MAN)Y. Straight to Bradford’s the moment I saw “navigator in the past” as this was obviously going to be one of those solutions solely there to plug an awkward space. Setters waste no time deploying crap like this when put into a tight spot, so why should we?

across.text: Newly baked buns close toWeihnachten: a German institution!
across.explanation: BUNDESBANK(i.e. “a German institution”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “newly”) of BAKED BUNS and N (i.e. “close to Weihnachten”, i.e. the last letter of Weihnachten).

across.text: Symbol of bear seen by millions
across.explanation: TOTEM(i.e. “symbol”). Solution is TOTE (i.e. to carry or “bear”) followed by M (a recognised abbreviation of “millions”).

across.text: Girl clips rail exercising
across.explanation: PRISCILLA(i.e. a “girl’s” name). “Exercising” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of CLIPS RAIL.

across.text: A number of just people excluded from company?
across.explanation: ONLY THE LONELY(i.e. “a number” by Roy Orbison). Solution is ONLY (i.e. “just”) followed by THE LONELY (i.e. “people excluded from company”).

across.text: Want to take in film with female: a recent catch?
across.explanation: WET FISH(i.e. “a recent catch”, as opposed to frozen or dried fish). Solution is WISH (i.e. “want”) wrapped around or “taking in” ET (i.e. “film”, specificallyET: The Extra Terrestrial) and F (a recognised abbreviation of “female”), like so: W(ET-F)ISH.

across.text: Port to progress slowly with age
across.explanation: INCHEON(i.e. a “port” of South Korea). Solution is INCH (i.e. “to progress slowly”) followed by EON (i.e. “age”). Again to Bradford’s for pretty much the same reason as 1a. Who cares how easy the parsing is? If you see “port” in a clue, you have my permission to be a big cheating bastard like me. Bradford’s alone lists 900 of them. Are you going to sit there and learn them all? For a crossword? Really? No, of course not. Treat it like the lazy cop-out it is, cheat and move on.

across.text: One making mistake: he’s put his foot in it?
across.explanation: SLIPPER. Solution satisfies “one making mistake” – playfully, hence the riddly question mark – and “he’s put his foot in it”.

across.text: With passion, elected representative repeated lines of poetry
across.explanation: I REMEMBER I REMEMBER(i.e. “lines of poetry” by Thomas Hood). Solution is IRE (i.e. “passion”) and MEMBER (i.e. “elected representative”) “repeated”.

across.text: From a piece of furniture, article’s removed
across.explanation: AS OF(i.e. “from”). Solution is A followed by SOFA (i.e. “piece of furniture”) once the A has been removed (indicated by “article’s removed”, an article is a word like a, an or the), like so: A-SOF.

across.text: Pass out from worry
across.explanation: EXEAT(i.e. a “pass” or “formal leave of absence, especially for a student to be out of college for more than one night”(Chambers)). Solution is EX (i.e. Latin for “out from”) followed by EAT (i.e. “worry”, as in “what’s eating you?”). Not one I’m familiar with, not being of that bracket, but nicely worked all the same.

across.text: Leaves here couple on golf course for picking up?
across.explanation: TEA CADDY(i.e. “leaves here”). Solution comprises homophones (indicated by “for picking up”) of TEE and CADDIE (i.e. “couple on golf course”), despite CADDY being an acceptable variant spelling of the latter.

across.text: Grey exterior to tower that is becoming darker
across.explanation: GLOOMIER(i.e. “darker”). Solution is GR (a recognised abbreviation of “grey”) wrapped around or being “exterior to” LOOM (i.e. “to tower”) and IE (i.e. “that is”, i.e. …um… i.e.!), like so: G(LOOM-IE)R.

across.text: Prayer leader embracing wife with an expression of disbelief
across.explanation: I’M A DUTCHMAN(i.e. “expression of disbelief”). Solution is IMAM (i.e. “prayer leader”) wrapped around or “embracing” DUTCH (i.e. “wife” – supposedly cockney rhyming slang after the Duchess of Fife) and followed by AN, like so: IMA(DUTCH)M-AN.

across.text: Boss, after row, one getting on with staff
across.explanation: LINE MANAGER(i.e. “boss”). Solution is LINE (i.e. “row”) followed by AGER (i.e. “one getting on”) once placed “on” or after MAN (i.e. to “staff” an operation), like so: LINE-(MAN-AGER).

across.text: Reporters of contests involving sailors and boxer
across.explanation: JOURNALISTS(i.e. “reporters”). Solution is JOUSTS (i.e. “contests”) wrapped around or “involving” RN (i.e. “sailors”, specifically the Royal Navy) and Muhammad ALI (i.e. “boxer”), like so: JOU(RN-ALI)STS.

across.text: What spectacularly sparks love affair and also large splits
across.explanation: ROMAN CANDLE(i.e. “what spectacularly sparks”). Solution is ROMANCE (i.e. “love affair”) wrapped around or “split” by AND (i.e. “also”) and L (a recognised abbreviation of “large”), like so: ROMANC(AND-L)E. Nicely worked.

across.text: Where US driver pulls in – and remains in pole position
across.explanation: REST STOP(i.e. “where US driver pulls in”). Solution is RESTS (i.e. “remains”) followed by TOP (i.e. “in pole position”).

across.text: Sword that is needed by impressionist, to cut
across.explanation: SCIMITAR(i.e. “sword”). Solution is SC (i.e. “that is”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of the Latinscilicet) followed by IMITATOR (i.e. “impressionist”) once the “TO” has been “cut”, like so: SC-IMITAR.

across.text: Note is the writer’s – mostly the writer’s
across.explanation: MINIM(i.e. musical “note”). Solution is MINE (i.e. “the writer’s” from the point of view of the setter) once the last letter has been removed (indicated by “mostly”) and the remainder followed by I’M (i.e. “the writer’s”, again from the point of view of the setter – this time a contraction of I AM), like so: MIN-I’M.

across.text: You must not assume this at the outset
across.explanation: DON’T(i.e. “you must not”). Solution is DON (i.e. “assume”) followed by T (i.e. “this at the outset”, i.e. the first letter of “this”).

across.text: Rage, and split with the Foundation, as McCarthy did?
across.explanation: SEE REDS UNDER THE BED(i.e. “as McCarthy did”, specifically Senator Joseph McCarthy, who had an unhealthy obsession for alleged communists in 1950s America. Thank goodness we’ll never see such craziness again in US politics.(Looks to camera)). Solution is SEE RED (i.e. “rage”) followed by SUNDER (i.e. “split”), then THE and BED (i.e. “foundation” – ignore the misleading capitalisation).

across.text: Host outside departs in vain for key
across.explanation: MIDDLE C(i.e. musical “key”). Solution is MC (i.e. “host” or Master of Ceremonies) wrapped “outside” of D (a recognised abbreviation of “departs” used on timetables) once it as been placed “in” IDLE (i.e. “vain” – one of its lesser used meanings), like so: M(ID(D)LE)C.

across.text: Stole or cape to wear if held out
across.explanation: FILCHED(i.e. “stole”). Solution is C (a recognised abbreviation of “cape”, the geographic feature) placed in or “wearing” an anagram (indicated by “out”) of IF HELD, like so: FIL(C)HED.

across.text: City of Prague I fancy
across.explanation: PERUGIA(i.e. Italian “city”). “Fancy” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of PRAGUE I.

across.text: Proposal for an evening out?
across.explanation: LAW OF AVERAGES– over to Chambers for the official word: “popularly, a proposition stating that the mean of a situation is maintained by the averaging of its extremes”, so a flattening or “evening out”. Very nicely done.

across.text: Difficulty at end of term making entrance
across.explanation: SPELLBIND(i.e. “entrance”). Solution is BIND (i.e. “difficulty”) placed after or “at end of” SPELL (i.e. “term”).

across.text: Case of Arneis for one to try
across.explanation: ASSAY(i.e. to test or “try”). Solution is AS (i.e. “case of Arneis”, i.e. the first and last letter of “Arneis”) followed by SAY (i.e. for example or “for one”).

across.text: Ill-disposed to prisoner being taken in again
across.explanation: RESORPTION(i.e. “taken in again”). “Ill-disposed” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TO PRISONER.

across.text: Rubber of bridge players put in unusual on reflection
across.explanation: ERASER(i.e. “rubber”). Solution is S and E (i.e. “bridge players”, specifically recognised abbreviations of south and east) “put in” RARE (i.e. “unusual”) once reversed (indicated by “on reflection”), like so: ERA(SE)R.

down.text: Work in office perhaps, kind laid on with ceremony
down.explanation: TYPEWRITE(i.e. “work in office perhaps”). Solution is TYPE (i.e. “kind”) followed by W (a recognised abbreviation of “with”) and RITE (i.e. “ceremony”).

down.text: Remote country doctors alienate NHS
down.explanation: SAINT HELENA(i.e. “remote country”). “Doctors” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of ALIENATES NHS.

down.text: Ace writer gets credit
down.explanation: ASCRIBE(i.e. to “credit”). Solution is A (a recognised abbreviation of “ace” used on playing cards) followed by SCRIBE (i.e. “writer”).

down.text: Taste something in rum amiss
down.explanation: UMAMI(i.e. a sense of “taste”). “Something in” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: R(UM AMI)SS. One I remembered from an age-old episode of QI, to be honest.

down.text: What’s released from flies that’s sweet, leading to death, mostly
down.explanation: DROP CURTAIN(i.e. “what’s released from flies” – one definition of “flies” is “the large space above the proscenium in a theatre, from which the scenes, etc are controlled”(Chambers)). Solution is DROP (i.e. a “sweet”) followed by CURTAINS (i.e. “death”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “mostly”).

down.text: Pirate left to cross sea with a lesser prize?
down.explanation: SILVER MEDAL(i.e. “lesser prize”). I’m not going to tangle myself up in the clunky parsing here. Solution basically comprises Long John SILVER (i.e. “pirate”), MED (i.e. “sea”, specifically the Mediterranean), A and L (a recognised abbreviation of “left”).

down.text: Too many beginning to unilaterally agitate for independence
down.explanation: AUTONOMY(i.e. “independence”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “agitate”) of TOO MANY and U (i.e. “beginning [letter] to unilaterally”).

down.text: Seek new, unusual lines for organ part
down.explanation: KNEE-SWELL(i.e. “organ part”, of the musical instrument variety). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “unusual”) of SEEK NEW followed by L and L (i.e. “lines” – L being a recognised abbreviation of “line”), like so: KNEESWE-LL.

down.text: Cheap brace, a metal mouthpiece
down.explanation: TWO-BIT(i.e. “cheap”). Solution is TWO (i.e. a “brace”) followed by BIT (i.e. “a metal mouthpiece” for, say, horses).

down.text: Unlawful attendance in lycée’s very short-lived
down.explanation: TRESPASSING(i.e. “unlawful attendance”). Solution is TRES (i.e. “in lycée’s very”, basically the French for “very”) followed by PASSING (i.e. “short-lived”).

down.text: Dignitary dressing right
down.explanation: MAYOR(i.e. “dignitary”). Solution is MAYO (i.e. “dressing”, specifically mayonnaise) followed by R (a recognised abbreviation of “right”).

down.text: What order’s observed in abbey (or almost)
down.explanation: ALPHABETICAL. Clue plays on how the letters of “abbey” and “almost” are in alphabetical order.

down.text: Back in need of nurse – and doctor on the way
down.explanation: REARMOST(i.e. “back”). Solution is REAR (i.e. to “nurse”) followed by MO (i.e. “doctor” or Medical Officer) and ST (i.e. “way”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “street”).

down.text: Wood producer not oddly seen off in retort ever
down.explanation: FIR TREE(i.e. “wood producer”). “Not oddly seen” indicates we want only the even letters of OFFINRETORTEVER.

down.text: Method of delivery of bullet with gun
down.explanation: ROUND-ARM(i.e. “method of delivery” of a ball). Solution is ROUND (i.e. “bullet”) followed by ARM (i.e. “gun”).

down.text: Being tense when instructed to speak out by Head
down.explanation: TAUTNESS(i.e. “being tense”). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “to speak”) of TAUGHT (i.e. “instructed”) followed by NESS (i.e. “head”, geographical features – ignore the misleading capitalisation), like so: TAUT-NESS.

down.text: A button on the end, one coupled with zip?
down.explanation: ANIMATED(i.e. “with zip”). Solution is A followed by N (i.e. “button on the end”, i.e. the last letter of “button”), then I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and MATED (i.e. “coupled”).

down.text: Used to hold jack so unable to play?
down.explanation: INJURED(i.e. “unable to play” sports). Solution is INURED (i.e. “used to”) wrapped around or “holding” J (a recognised abbreviation of “jack” used on playing cards), like so: IN(J)URED.

down.text: Joel was one awfully hard prep monitor!
down.explanation: MINOR PROPHET(i.e. “Joel was one” – I bet it didn’t say that on his business card. I bet it said “BIG ASS PROPHET” in gold lettering or something). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “awfully”) of H (a recognised abbreviation of “hard” used in grading pencils) and PREP MONITOR.

down.text: At college hospital, doctor has varying fortunes
down.explanation: UPS AND DOWNS(i.e. “varying fortunes”). Solution is UP (i.e. “at college”) followed by SAN (i.e. “hospital”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of a sanatorium) and OWNS (i.e. “has”).

down.text: American stunner to perform in hit record with Queen
down.explanation: SOCKDOLOGER(i.e. “American stunner”, specifically old US slang for a hard or decisive blow. Not a word I’ve come across, but then I haven’t read a whole lot of Twain and his ilk. Great word, though). Solution is DO (i.e. “to perform”) placed “in” between SOCK (i.e. “hit”) and LOG (i.e. “record”), and followed by ER (i.e. “queen”, specifically Elizabeth Regina), like so: (SOCK-(DO)-LOG)-ER

down.text: After drink, our Henry needs a rest, they say
down.explanation: RUMOUR HAS IT(i.e. “they say”). Solution is RUM (i.e. “drink”) followed by OUR, then H (a recognised abbreviation of “Henry”, a unit of measurement that’s been like catnip for setters this last year), then A and SIT (i.e. “rest”).

down.text: Guides began to manoeuvre vehicles on beach
down.explanation: DUNE BUGGIES(i.e. “vehicles on beach”). “To manoeuvre” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of GUIDES BEGAN.

down.text: A dozen balls to hold in clubs in Bury
down.explanation: OVERCOVER(i.e. “bury” – ignore the misleading capitalisation). Solution is OVER and OVER (i.e. two overs or “a dozen balls” in cricket) wrapped around or “holding” C (a recognised abbreviation of “clubs” used in card games), like so: OVER-(C)-OVER.

down.text: Brummie maybe in dark turning up with lighter?
down.explanation: MIDLANDER(i.e. “Brummie maybe”). Solution is DIM (i.e. “in dark”) reversed (indicated by “turning up” – this being a down clue) and followed by LANDER (i.e. “lighter”, both vessels), like so: MID-LANDER.

down.text: As we used to say, you favour writing, music, sculpture etc
down.explanation: ART FORMS(i.e. “music, sculpture etc”). When written as ART FOR MS the solution satisfies “as we used to say, you favour writing”. MS is a recognised abbreviation of “manuscript”, while ART is a ye olde form of “are” that’s getting to be as overused in these Jumbos as “Henry”.

down.text: Irish sportsperson eclipsing fourth-rate track athlete
down.explanation: HURDLER(i.e. “track athlete”). Solution is HURLER (i.e. “Irish sportsman”) wrapped around or “eclipsing” D (i.e. “fourth-rate”, i.e. a D grade), like so: HUR(D)LER.

down.text: Having a nap on top of yardarm is mistake
down.explanation: FLUFFY(i.e. “having a nap” or downy covering). Solution is FLUFF (i.e. “mistake”, as in fluffing one’s lines) placed “on” or before Y (i.e. “top of yardarm”, i.e. the first letter of “yardarm”).

down.text: Old singer, close to stardom, rising up to it
down.explanation: Dame NellieMELBA(i.e. “old singer”). Solution is M (i.e. “close to stardom”, i.e. the last letter of “stardom”) followed by ABLE (i.e. “up to it”) once reversed (indicated by “rising” – this being a down clue), like so: M-ELBA. An easier get after I somehow remembered her from her last appearance, back in grid 1488. I wonder if remembering stuff like this is why I can never remember anyone’s birthday.

down.text: Lively music, remarkably taken fromRevelation
down.explanation: DISCO(i.e. “lively music”). Solution is DISCOVERY (i.e. “revelation” – ignoring the misleading capitalisation) once the VERY has been removed (indicated by “remarkably taken from…”).
